articles.title: Chelsea transfer news: Blues bid £105m for Enzo Fernandez
articles.description: Chelsea make a 120m euro (£105.6m) bid for Benfica's Argentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez in a move that would break the British transfer record.
articles.content:
Last updated on .From the section Chelsea
Chelsea have bid 120m euros (£105.6m) for Benfica's Argentina midfielder Enzo Fernandez in a move that would break the British transfer record.

articles.title: Frustration for Sam Bennett on final stage of Vuelta a San Juan in Argentina
articles.description: Bora-hansgrohe team was further back than his key rivals heading into the final two kilometres
articles.content:
Sam Bennett had a frustrating end to the Vuelta a San Juan in Argentina on Sunday night, aiming for his second stage victory of the race but being impeded in what was a very messy sprint.
Bennett’s Bora-hansgrohe team was further back than those of h... [1623 chars]

articles.title: Enzo Fernandez to Chelsea: Sergio Aguero believes big money transfer is only ‘a short time away’
articles.description: Blues pushing to make stunning £105m move for Argentina star
articles.content:
S ergio Aguero has tipped Enzo Fernandez for an imminent move to the Premier League.
The Argentina midfielder is Chelsea’s leading target before the end of the window and the Blues are prepared to send a delegation to Lisbon for talks with Benfica.

articles.title: Watch: Novak Djokovic sings ‘Muchachos’, the song that made Argentina popular at the World Cup
articles.description: The song “Muchachos” that references Messi, Maradona, and Argentina’s hopes erupted into a viral song ever since Messi himself said on a TV channel that it was one of his favourite football songs.
articles.content:
In a video that’s going viral on the internet, tennis star Novak Djokovic can be heard chanting the song “Muchachos” that made Argentina popular at the Qatar World Cup.

articles.title: Krugman Calls Brazil and Argentina's South American Euro Plan a 'Terrible Idea'
articles.description: A shared currency would work best for countries that are each other's biggest trading partners, Krugman said.
articles.content:
Paul Krugman criticized Brazil and Argentina's plan to create a common currency for trade.
"It's a nice opportunity to apply the theory of Optimum Currency Areas — which tells us that it's a terrible idea," he said on Twitter.
